facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 16, 1963 of the Gujarat High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 154 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 16, 1963 of the Gujarat High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 154 of 1962.

facts.text: The appellant and six other persons were charged under ss. 4 and 5 of the Bombay Prevention of Gambling Act 1887.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and six other persons were charged under ss. 4 and 5 of the Bombay Prevention of Gambling Act 1887.

facts.text: Sub-inspector of police Shri Anjaria received information that the appellant was keeping a common gaming house.

anchor.surface_text: The sub-inspector of police Shri Anjaria received information that the appellant was keeping a companymon gaming house.

facts.text: Shri Anjaria obtained a special search warrant from the Deputy Superintendent of Police, Porbandar, Shri S. M. Pandya.

anchor.surface_text: He obtained a special search warrant from the Deputy Superintendent of Police, Porbandar, Shri S. M. Pandya, and raided the appellants house in Bantwa on June 4, 1961 at 1 p.m.

facts.text: Raided the appellant's house in Bantwa on June 4, 1961 at 1 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: and raided the appellants house in Bantwa on June 4, 1961 at 1 p.m.

facts.text: The raiding party found the door leading to the upper floor closed.

anchor.surface_text: The raiding arty found the door leadin- to the upper floor closed.

facts.text: The inmates pressed against the door from the inside and did not open it until a blacksmith broke open the latch.

anchor.surface_text: The inpmates pressed against the door from the inside and did number open it until a blacksmith broke open the latch.

facts.text: Shri Anjaria seized torn and burnt pieces of playing cards lying on the floor of the central room.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Anjaria seized torn and burnt pieces of playing cards lying on the floor of the central room, two packs of cards from a wall cabinet,

facts.text: Seized two packs of cards from a wall cabinet.

anchor.surface_text: , two packs of cards from a wall cabinet, some burnt cards lying on the floor and in the folds of a bed in the drawing room,

facts.text: Seized some burnt cards lying on the floor and in the folds of a bed in the drawing room.

anchor.surface_text: some burnt cards lying on the floor and in the folds of a bed in the drawing room, four jokers and three packs of cards from trunks in the kitchen,

facts.text: Seized four jokers and three packs of cards from trunks in the kitchen.

anchor.surface_text: four jokers and three packs of cards from trunks in the kitchen, some cash, burnt cigarette ends, bidis and matches and empty cigarette cases.

facts.text: Seized some cash, burnt cigarette ends, bidis and matches and empty cigarette cases.

anchor.surface_text: some cash, burnt cigarette ends, bidis and matches and empty cigarette cases. All the accused were found in the upper floor.

facts.text: All the accused were found in the upper floor.

anchor.surface_text: All the accused were found in the upper floor.

facts.text: The appellant as the occupant of the house was charged under s. 4 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant as the occupant of the house was charged under s. 4 of the Act and the other six accused were charged under s. 5 of the Act.

facts.text: The other six accused were charged under s. 5 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: and the other six accused were charged under s. 5 of the Act.

facts.text: The learned magistrate refused to raise a presumption under s. 7 of the Act on the ground that Shri Pandya was not specially empowered by name to issue a search warrant.

anchor.surface_text: The learned magistrate refused to raise a presumption under s. 7 of the Act on the ground that Shri Pandya was number specially empowered by name to issue a search warrant.

facts.text: Magistrate acquitted all the accused.

anchor.surface_text: He acquitted all the accused.

facts.text: On appeal, the High Court held that Shri Pandya as the deputy superintendent of police, Porbandar was specially empowered to issue the search warrant.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the High Court held that Shri Pandya as the deputy superintendent of police, Porbandar was specially empowered to issue the search warrant and the prosecution was entitled to the benefit of the presumption under s. 7.

facts.text: High Court convicted the appellant of the offence under s. 4 of the Act and sentenced him to simple imprisonment for one month.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court companyvicted the appellant of the offence under s. 4 of the Act and sentenced him to simple imprisonment for one month.

facts.text: High Court convicted the other six accused under s. 5 of the Act and sentenced each of them to pay a fine of Rs. 200, in default simple imprisonment for one month.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court companyvicted the other six accused under.,,. 5 of the Act and sentenced each of them to pay a fine of Rs. 200, in default simple imprisonment for one month.

facts.text: The present appeal was filed by the appellant by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: The present appeal was filed by the appellant by special leave.

facts.text: By a notification dated January 22, 1955, the Saurashtra government empowered specially certain assistant superintendents and deputy superintendents of police including the deputy superintendent of police, Porbandar Division, Porbandar, to authorise by issue of special warrants.

anchor.surface_text: By a numberification dated January 22, 1955, the Saurashtra government empowered specially certain assistant superintendents and deputy superintendents of police including the deputy superintendent of police, Porbandar Division, Porbandar, to authorise by issue of special warrants in each case a police officer number below the rank of a sub-inspector of police to do the various things necessary in order to raid a house where the police officer suspected gaming to be carried on and which house, room or place was suspected as being used as a companymon gaming house.

facts.text: It is conceded that the notification continued to be in force after the merger of Saurashtra with the State of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: It is companyceded that the numberification companytinued to be in force after the merger of Saurashtra with the State of Bombay.

facts.text: The seizure of instruments of gaming in the appellants house entered under s. 6 raises a presumption under s. 7 that the house was used as a common gaming house.

anchor.surface_text: The seizure of instruments of gaming in the appellants house entered under s. 6 raises a presumption under s. 7 that the house was used as a companymon gaming house and the persons found therein were then present for the purpose of gaming.

facts.text: The appellant could not successfully rebut the presumption.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the appellant companyld number successfully rebut the presumption.

facts.text: The resistance to the entry of the sub inspector and the attempt to burn, destroy and conceal the playing cards fortified the presumption.

anchor.surface_text: The resistance to the entry of the sub inspector and the attempt to burn, destroy and companyceal the playing cards fortified the presumption.

facts.text: The explanation that the appellant had invited friends and relatives on the occasion of his sons betrothal was not convincing.

anchor.surface_text: The explanation that the appellant had invited friends and relatives on the occasion of his sons betrothal was number companyvincing.

facts.text: No prejudice was caused to the appellant by the production of the notification dated January 22, 1955 for the first time at the appellate stage.

anchor.surface_text: No prejudice was caused to the appellant by the production of the numberification dated January 22, 1955 for the first time at the appellate stage.

facts.text: The High Court rightly convicted the appellant under s. 4 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rightly companyvicted the appellant under s. 4 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Section 15 of the Bombay General Clauses Act 1904 shows that a person may be appointed to execute any function either by name or by virtue of office. A person may therefore be empowered by name or by virtue of his office of deputy superintendent of police to issue a special search warrant.

anchor.surface_text: For the meaning of the expression specially empowered reference is often made to s. 9 of the Code of Criminal Procedure which provides in conferring powers under this Code, the State Government may by order, empower persons specially by name or in virtue of their office or classes of officials generally by their official titles.

concepts.interpretation: Analogy for 'specially empowered' includes by virtue of office

holdings.text: Shri Pandya as the holder of the office of the deputy superintendent of police, Porbandar was specially empowered under s. 6 of the Bombay Prevention of Gambling Act by the notification of the Saurashtra government dated January 22, 1955

anchor.surface_text: We hold that Shri Pandya as the holder of the office of the deputy superintendent of police, Porbandar was specially empowered under s. 6 of the Bombay Prevention of Gambling Act by the numberification of the Saurashtra government dated January 22, 1955.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notification empowers holder of specific office; supported by s.15 Bombay General Clauses Act allowing empowerment by office; follows Emperor v. Savlaram; distinguishes Emperor v. Udho; analogies to CrPC ss.9,39

holdings.text: The seizure of instruments of gaming in the appellant's house entered under s. 6 raises a presumption under s. 7 that the house was used as a common gaming house and the persons found therein were then present for the purpose of gaming; the presumption applies with circumspection but was not rebutted here

anchor.surface_text: The seizure of instruments of gaming in the appellants house entered under s. 6 raises a presumption under s. 7 that the house was used as a companymon gaming house and the persons found therein were then present for the purpose of gaming. In applying this artificial pre- sumption the Court should act with circumspection. Playing cards may be kept

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory artificial rebuttable presumption triggered by valid seizure; rebuttal fails due to unconvincing explanation of son's betrothal, resistance to entry, and attempts to burn/destroy cards which fortify it

holdings.text: No prejudice was caused to the appellant by the production of the notification dated January 22, 1955 for the first time at the appellate stage

anchor.surface_text: No prejudice was caused to the appellant by the production of the numberification dated January 22, 1955 for the first time at the appellate stage.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant had opportunity to rebut s.7 presumption and did not seek further time; prior contention was on sufficiency not production

holdings.text: The point that the search warrant was invalid as it did not ex-facie set out the authority under which it was issued will not be allowed to be raised

The point was not taken either in the High Court or in the special leave petition. We therefore indicated that we will not allow this point to be raised.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Point not raised in High Court or special leave petition; appellate practice precludes new points

anchor.surface_text: The magistrate relying upon Emperor v. Udho and others 1 , held that under s. 6, the officer must be specially empowered by name. The High Court relying on Emperor v. Savlaram Kashinath Joshi,  2  held that an officer may be specially empowered under s. 6 either by name or, in virtue of his office.

precedents.cited_proposition: under s. 6, the officer must be specially empowered by name

anchor.surface_text: The High Court relying on Emperor v. Savlaram Kashinath Joshi,  2  held that an officer may be specially empowered under s. 6 either by name or, in virtue of his office. It is because of the companyflict of opinion between the Sind and the Bombay decisions that special leave was granted in this case.

precedents.cited_proposition: an officer may be specially empowered under s. 6 either by name or, in virtue of his office

anchor.surface_text: In Emperor v. Udho and others 1 , the expression specially empowered was interpreted to mean specially empowered by name and number by virtue of his office, and an authorization of the deputy superintendent of police, Rohri was said to be insufficient for the purposes of s. 6.

precedents.cited_proposition: specially empowered means specially empowered by name and not by virtue of his office; authorization of deputy superintendent insufficient
precedents.cited_holding: authorization of the deputy superintendent of police, Rohri was said to be insufficient for the purposes of s. 6

anchor.surface_text: In Emperor Savlaram Kashinath Joshi 2  it was rightly held that a numberification authorizing the deputy superintendent of police of the Poona city to issue a search warrant under s. 6 specially empowered the holder of that office by virtue of his office to issue the warrant.

precedents.cited_proposition: notification authorizing deputy superintendent of police of Poona city specially empowers holder of office by virtue of office
precedents.cited_holding: a numberification authorizing the deputy superintendent of police of the Poona city to issue a search warrant under s. 6 specially empowered the holder of that office by virtue of his office

We do number ex- press any opinion on those questions, as it is number the practice of this Court to express opinion on questions which do number arise for decision. For the purpose of this case, it is sufficient to hold that a numberification companyferring power on the deputy superintendent of police of Porbandar to issue a search warrant specially empowers the holder of that office by virtue of his office to issue the warrant.

Bombay General Clauses Act Section 15 supports empowering by office for statutory functions, which supports the holding that Shri Pandya was specially empowered as holder of the office under s. 6 of the Bombay Prevention of Gambling Act.

anchor.surface_text: We hold that Shri Pandya as the holder of the office of the deputy superintendent of police, Porbandar was specially empowered under s. 6 of the Bombay Prevention of Gambling Act by the numberification of the Saurashtra government dated January 22, 1955.

We do not find any compelling reason for interfering with the findings of fact by the High Court. A.I.R. 1924 Mad. 256.  2 A.I.R, 1915 Mad. 1159.  3  1963 2  Cr.L. J. 226.  4  A.I.R. 1953 Assam 35.  5  1953 I.L.R. Trav.-Co 514 A.I.R 1956 Saurashtra 73. No prejudice was caused to the appellant by the production of the notification dated January 22, 1955 for the first time at the appellate stage.

anchor.surface_text: The seizure of instruments of gaming in the appellants house entered under s. 6 raises a presumption under s. 7 that the house was used as a companymon gaming house and the persons found therein were then present for the purpose of gaming. anchor.surface_text: Counsel sought to argue that the search warrant was invalid as it did not ex-facie set out the authority under which it was issued. The point was not taken either in the High Court or in the special leave petition. We therefore indicated that we will not allow this point to be raised.
